entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - From Provisioning to Intelligent Applications
entry.content:
Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud

In this blog, we will try to go over the Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and then the Components and Building Blocks of SAP BDC.

SAP BDC is a fully managed software-as-a-service (SaaS) offering from SAP designed to address the need of managing vast volumes of data originating from diverse systems. It consolidates and governs all SAP data while seamlessly integrating third-party sources, delivering contextualized, trusted data to business leaders for more impactful decision-making. By harmonizing mission-critical data into a unified semantic layer, the platform eliminates the overhead of data extraction and replication.  Supporting a wide range of use cases across industries and business functions, SAP BDC ensures that data is consistently accessible, secure, and ready for advanced analytics.

Key Aspects of SAP Business Data Cloud

  • Intelligent Applications: AI-driven apps that leverage your data and business context to automate processes, adapt dynamically, and drive transformative outcomes in real time.
  • Data Products: Prebuilt, customizable, and governed data assets that come enriched with business semantics, documentation, and APIsâ€”accelerating deployment across a wide range of use cases.
  • Business Data Fabric: A comprehensive data and analytics foundation that integrates SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, modernized SAP Business Warehouse, data engineering capabilities, and AI/ML innovations through SAP Databricks.
  • AI-Enriched Decision Making: Enterprise-grade tools that deliver responsible, context-aware AI for reporting and analytics â€”empowering smarter, faster decisions.

Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Source Systems:  SAP BDC connects seamlessly to various source systemsâ€”such as SAP S/4HANAâ€”to identify and extract key business data entities. These include tables, views, and other structures that contain mission-critical data across domains like HR, finance, supply chain. By integrating with these systems, SAP BDC ensures that foundational business data is readily available for analytics, governance, and intelligent application development.

Foundational Services in SAP Business Data Cloud: Within SAP BDC, data extracted from source systems flows into the Foundation Services layer. This foundational component is responsible for ingesting, integrating, cleansing, and harmonizing both structured and unstructured data. It ensures that the data is properly aligned and enriched as part of SAP-managed Data Products, forming the backbone of trusted, analytics-ready information across the SAP BDC landscape.

SAP Datasphere: SAP Datasphere serves as the modeling and governance layer atop the BDC Semantic Layer. It provides a robust set of tools for designing analytical data models, defining business logic, managing data lineage, enforcing governance and security. In addition to its core modeling capabilities, SAP Datasphere supports machine learning and AI extensions, making it a foundational component for advanced analytics and intelligent decision-making. Datasphere acts as the data engine behind SAP Analytics Cloud, feeding it with both prebuilt and custom insights for reporting and visualization. It also enables customers to create custom data products using the SAP Datasphere Object Store, which supports zero-copy data access via the Delta Sharing Protocol - ensuring efficient, secure, and scalable data sharing across the enterprise.

SAP Databricks: SAP Databricks is a specialized integration of the Databricks platform embedded directly within SAP BDC. It combines industry-leading capabilities in AI, machine learning, data science, and data engineering with semantically rich, business-ready data from SAP applications. This component significantly enhances analytics by enabling generative AI scenariosâ€”without the need for complex data pipelines. Through zero-copy Delta Sharing, SAP Databricks connects directly to SAP Data Products, allowing seamless access and enrichment of data without replication. By bridging enterprise-grade SAP data with the flexibility of Databricks, organizations can accelerate innovation, streamline operations, and unlock deeper insights across their business landscape.

SAP Analytics Cloud: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) empowers business analytics by directly consuming integrated data from the SAP Datasphere component within BDC. It supports rich visualization, reporting, and AI-driven analytics across the enterpriseâ€”all within a unified, cloud-based SaaS environment. By leveraging semantically aligned data from Datasphere, SAC enables organizations to generate actionable insights, build dynamic dashboards, and drive informed decision-making at scale.

SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA Integration: To support legacy compatibility, SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA objects can be technically onboarded into SAP BDC. This integration enables organizations to migrate data and maintain hybrid use casesâ€”bridging traditional data warehousing with modern cloud-based analyticsâ€”until the official end-of-support timeline for BW systems. By incorporating BW artifacts into BDC, businesses can preserve existing investments while gradually transitioning to a unified, governed, and AI-ready data landscape.

Building Blocks of SAP Business Data Cloud

Provisioning an SAP Business Data Cloud Tenant

An SAP BDC tenant is provisioned via the SAP for Me portal using a guided, self-service workflow. This process enables organizations to activate and configure the components of SAP Business Data Cloud according to their commercial entitlements. The provisioning journey begins with the BDC Core Component or Cockpit, which serves as the central management interface for the entire SAP BDC landscape. 

Once the BDC cockpit is provisioned, the next step is to provision (from SAP for Me) the core capabilities and applications, including: SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks.

After these systems are successfully provisioned through SAP for Me, users can  begin creating Formationsâ€”structured configurations that define how data products and applications are orchestrated across the landscape.

Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud

A Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud is a logical grouping of SAP systems and related components designed to support specific business scenarios or integration use cases. Formations simplify connectivity and provide a unified view of all systems, making it easier to manage integrations, extensions, and orchestrate data across the SAP BDC landscape.  Formations are created by selecting the required SAP systemsâ€”these must first be provisioned via the SAP for Me portal. Once provisioned, they appear in the Systems tab of the portal and can be included in one or more formations. Each formation can consist of multiple systems such as SAP BDC Core, SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP BW, SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks. These systems are synchronized within the formation to enable streamlined operations and cohesive business processes. Multiple formations can be created to support extended or complex business scenarios.

Benefits of Using Formations

  • Simplified Integration: Centralizes the grouping and management of systems required for a business scenario.
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Easily add or remove systems as organizational needs evolve.
  • Governance and Control: Enables centralized configuration and oversight, improving compliance and reducing maintenance overhead.

SAP Data Products in Business Data Cloud 

An SAP Data Product is a curated and refined dataset derived from data ingested from SAP solutions. It encompasses a Business Data Set that includes master data, transactional records, analytics datasets, and configuration dataâ€”all semantically aligned to ensure consistency and usability.

These datasets are enriched with meaningful metadata and documentation, making them easily consumable and understandable. Within the SAP BDC, Data Products serve as the core building blocks for Intelligent Applications, enabling advanced analytics and decision-making.  SAP delivers and manages these Data Products as part of its SaaS offering, maintaining full lifecycle ownership. However, customers can customize them to suit specific business needs. Each Data Product includes all necessary artifactsâ€”such as CDS views, connectors, flows, jobs, and lifecycle management toolsâ€”required to support its associated use cases within SAP BDC. They are easily discoverable through the SAP BDC product catalog. These products are designed by line-of-business experts to help organizations maximize the value of their data. Types of Data Products

  • Primary Data Products: Directly sourced from applications, representing original data from systems like SAP S/4HANA. They are not derived from other data products.
  • Derived Data Products: Built by SAP using existing datasets or APIs. This offer added value by combining or transforming data from multiple sources.

Custom or Customer Managed Data Products : SAP BDC also supports custom data products, which can be curated within SAP Datasphere. These leverage the Datasphere Object Store and Delta Sharing Protocol, enabling zero-copy data access for efficient and secure data sharing.

Intelligent Applications in SAP Business Data Cloud

Intelligent Applications are AI-driven, visualization-centric solutions designed to address specific business scenarios. Unlike general-purpose analytics tools, these applications are built with SAP-managed analytical assets and functionalities that deliver value through process, domain, or analytical intelligence. They typically include data products, semantic models, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) stories. These applications foster collaboration between analytics and data science teams by providing ready-made dashboards enriched with AI-generated insights. Their embedded business logic and contextual data models eliminate the need for organizations to build complex analytical frameworks from scratchâ€”saving time and resources. The core structure of Intelligent Applications includes:

  • SAC Stories: Serve as the front-end interface, offering rich visualizations tailored to specific analytics use cases.
  • SAP Datasphere Models and Views: Includes the backend logic and data orchestration.
  • Semantic Models and Story Templates: Combined to deliver reusable, customizable dashboards.

These applications are cataloged within the SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC), making them easy to discover, deploy, and extend.

Installation and Customization

To explore and install Intelligent Applications:

  1. Log in to the SAP BDC Cockpit. Browse the available applications and their documentation.
  2. Upon installation, a suite of artifacts is deployed across SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud, including Data Products, Replication Flows, Tables and Views, Analytic Models, Roles and Dashboards.

 Customization Guidelines

  • SAP-managed applications and their dependencies are read-only, but users can copy and adapt components.
  • SAC Stories can be duplicated and tailored to meet specific business needs.
  • For advanced scenarios, users may replicate and modify the underlying analytic models ( within SAP Datasphere).
  • Changes to models will affect both the original and copied stories, so version control and impact analysis are recommended.

Key Differentiation between Business Content and Intelligent Applications

  • Business Content provides a set of pre-built models and other artifacts, but customers manage the implementation, configuration and maintenance of these solutions.
  • Intelligent Applications are fully managed and curated by SAP and delivered as software-as-a-service designed to cater specific business use cases or scenarios.

Hope this helps you understand the basics and get started on SAP Business Data Cloud.

entry.title: Optimizing SAP Analytics Cloud â€“ Best Practices and Performance
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) offers powerful capabilities for planning, analytics, and business intelligenceâ€”all in one unified platform. But to truly unlock its potential, it's essential to follow best practices that ensure optimal performance, scalability, and maintainability. In this blog, weâ€™ll explore some of the insights and recommendations across four key pillars of SAC:

  • Analytics & Planning Modeling: Structuring your models for flexibility, performance, and future growth.
  • Calculations: Designing efficient formulas and leveraging SACâ€™s calculation engine wisely.
  • Data Actions: Automating planning workflows with precision and minimal overhead.
  • Story Building: Crafting intuitive, responsive, and insightful dashboards that drive decision-making.

Performance Considerations

Performance in SAC isnâ€™t a post-implementation concernâ€”it must be a core priority from the very beginning of your project. Striking the right balance between rich functionality and responsive performance is essential. While functional requirements drive business value, they must be matched by a system that performs reliably and efficiently. Performance optimization touches every layer of your SAC solution: from backend data architecture and model design to story layout, user concurrency, and even device and network configurations.

Model Design

  • Model Scope: Clearly define the modelâ€™s scope, type (planning or analytics), required metrics, and data granularity based on business objectives. This clarity prevents over engineering and ensures alignment with user needs.
  • Reusability: Build modular models that can be reused across multiple stories and planning scenarios. Reusability reduces duplication, simplifies maintenance, and accelerates development cycles.
  • Lean Model Structure: Key performance drivers include the number of measures, dimensions, hierarchies, and members per dimension. Reducing unnecessary dimensions and avoiding overly complex hierarchies directly improves query performance and system responsiveness. Focus on dimensions that are essential for data collection. Attributes such as geographic area or gender can often be derived rather than modeled as standalone dimensions. Evaluate whether static dimensions can be converted into attributes, and consider splitting large models into smaller, purpose-driven ones. Simpler models are easier to maintain, faster to calculate, and more memory efficient. Avoid adding dimensions or calculations unless they deliver clear business value.
  • Understanding Model Types: From a performance perspective, Analytic Models connected to live data sources place minimal demand on SAC infrastructure, as most of the processing load is handled by the source system itself. In contrast, Analytic Models using acquired data rely on the embedded HANA database, primarily for read operations. While this does introduce some system load, it tends to be moderate and more CPU-intensive than memory-intensive. Planning Models with acquired data, however, offer richer functionality but come with higher resource requirementsâ€”impacting both CPU and memory. Their performance is heavily influenced by model design factors such as the number of exception aggregations, the complexity and volume of dimensions, and the breadth of the userâ€™s security context during data entry operations.
  • Additional performance-critical factors include the number of concurrent users, the volume and structure of the data, and the frequency and complexity of scheduled jobs or data actions also play a significant role in determining system responsiveness and scalability.
  • Use Measure Based Model: When designing models in SAC, opting for a Measure-Based Model is highly recommended due to its significant advantages in performance, calculation flexibility, and overall modeling efficiency.
    • Enhanced Performance & Scalability: Measure-based models are optimized for faster processing and reduced complexity, especially in large-scale planning scenarios.
    • Flexible Structure: These models support both accounts and measures, with the account dimension now optional giving you greater design freedom.
    • Reusable Calculations: You can define base measure calculations that simplify logic reuse across stories and planning workflows.
    • Advanced Aggregation: Measures can be aggregated more efficiently, improving responsiveness and reducing load times.
    • Expanded Data Type Support: Measure-based models accommodate a wider range of data types, enhancing versatility.
    • Multi-Currency Planning: With base currency measures, currency conversion becomes seamless, enabling planning across multiple currencies with ease.

Dimension Design

  • Leverage Public Dimensions: Use the Public Dimension feature to manage master data independently, allowing for centralized updates and reuse across models. Avoid importing all source system tablesâ€”focus only on dimensions relevant to data entry and planning.
  • Dimension hierarchies and members: Deep hierarchies can be resource intensive. Limit the number of levels to reduce complexity and improve query performance. Keep the number of members in each dimensionâ€”including the Account dimensionâ€”lean. Import only valid members and apply filters to exclude irrelevant data.
  • Date Dimension: Use SACâ€™s standard date dimension with SAP-managed hierarchies (Yearâ€“Quarterâ€“Monthâ€“Day) to minimize performance impact.

Planning Area

  • The planning area defines the specific slice of data within a model that end users can interact withâ€”whether through stories or data actions. When users plan on a public version in a story, SAC automatically creates an implicit private version behind the scenes. This version isnâ€™t visible to the user but introduces system overhead, especially in models with large datasets or when multiple users are editing simultaneously. To mitigate this, itâ€™s crucial to explicitly define the planning area in the model settings and enable it within the story. Doing so significantly reduces resource consumption during public version edits. Key recommendations include:
  • Configure a Targeted Planning Area: Set a focused scope based on business needs, using data access control, data locking, or both to restrict editable data.
  • Avoid Full Dataset Scope: Limiting the planning area prevents unnecessary data loading and improves performance.
  • Use Data Access Control(DAC): Define which users can write to specific dimensionsâ€”such as company codes or profit centersâ€”to ensure secure and relevant access.
  • Apply Data Locking: Protect actuals from being overwritten by locking them from edits.
  • Enable Dynamic Planning Area: Set â€œAuto-generate based on table contextâ€ as the default. This allows the planning area to adjust automatically based on filters, story context, or table layoutâ€”ensuring users only load what they need.

SAC Planning Best Practices

  • Use Unbooked Data selectively: Enable unbooked data only when necessaryâ€”typically for planning use cases. Since it triggers resource-intensive backend queries, it's best disabled for reporting scenarios to preserve performance.
  • Implement DAC: Always activate DAC on relevant dimensions to enforce row-level security. This ensures users only see and interact with data within their authorized scope, reducing system load during public version edits. DAC should be configured during the model design phase. DAC can be turned ON in the Model Dimension through the Read/Write Property or the Data Access Filter in Role by turning the Model Data Privacy ON so DAC can be combined with role-based restrictions. Use DAC primarily on planning-relevant dimensions (E.g. Cost Center, Profit Center, Region), not on all dimensions.
  • Complement with Data Locks :  While DAC governs who can read/write data, Data Locks control when data can be modified (e.g., freezing approved budgets). This combination enhances performance, especially in multi-user environments. Minimize driving dimensions when using data locking to reduce overhead.
  • Define Validation Rules: Ensure users can only edit valid combinations of dimension members. This is particularly important for models with large dimension tables and helps maintain data integrity while improving performance.
  • Limit Private versions: Excessive private versionsâ€”especially when multiple users are editing simultaneouslyâ€”can strain system resources. Regularly clean up unused private versions to maintain system efficiency.
  • Manage Date Granularity: For models with day-level granularity, consider isolating them into separate models. Use cross-model copy data actions to transfer aggregated data, reducing complexity and improving performance.
  • Use Modeler option â€˜Optimize Story Building Performanceâ€™ : This prevents the automatic refresh of data during story design. When importing or writing back datasets, use filters or pre-aggregation to reduce data volume

Calculations/Data Actions

  • Prioritize Model-Level Formulas: Define calculations within the modeler rather than at the story level to reduce query load and improve responsiveness.
  • Offload Complex: Logic to Data Actions Use data actions for advanced formulas and heavy computations instead of embedding them directly in stories.
  • Restrict Execution Scope: Use the MEMBERSET statement to narrow the scope of data actions. A tightly defined scope minimizes processing time and resource usage.
  • Limit Iteration Range: Keep calculation loops (IF, FOREACH) as focused as possible. Broad iteration across dimensions can degrade performance.
  • Aggregate at the Highest Logical Level: Design calculations to occur at the most aggregated node feasible to reduce data volume and complexity.
  • Avoid Copying Calculated Accounts: Copying calculated accounts or non-standard aggregations is resource intensive. Prefer copying raw fact data when possible.
  • Configure Advanced Formulas Thoughtfully: All steps in advanced formulas execute sequentially and materialize in the model. Use variable members to streamline logic and avoid unnecessary commits.
  • Minimize Query Calls: Reduce the number of DATA() and RESULTLOOKUP() statementsâ€”each call triggers a backend query.
  • Restricted Measures Over Exception Aggregations: Exception aggregations (e.g., MIN, MAX, AVERAGE across hierarchies) are computationally expensive. Use restricted measures and advanced formulas when possible.
  • Simplify Formula Structures: Avoid breaking formulas into too many sub-steps, which increases processing overhead.
  • Recompile After Model Changes:  If performance drops after model updates, re-save the advanced formula or data action to trigger recompilation and optimization.
  • Centralize Execution for Large Volumes:  Run data actions centrally via an admin user when handling large datasets. For decentralized execution, ensure scope is tightly defined.
  • Trigger Actions Judiciously:  Avoid frequent or unnecessary data action runs. Execute only when required to conserve resources.
  • Monitor Execution Time:  Use the Data Action Monitor to track duration and identify slow-running actions.
  • Use Job Monitor for Diagnostics: Regularly review run history and step-level details to pinpoint bottlenecks and optimize performance.
  • Simplify IF Statements: Reduce reliance on IF statements by using logical operators like AND or applying filters. Each IF creates a subquery, so use sparingly.
  • Leverage Predictive Planning: Use predictive features to generate accurate forecasts based on historical data, accelerating planning cycles and improving decision-making.

Backend HANA/BW considerations

HANA modelling

  • Optimize HANA Views by following guidelines for modelling and performance tuning.
  • Perform Calculations Post-Aggregation: Whenever possible, structure views to calculate after aggregation to reduce data volume and improve speed.
  • Join on Indexed Columns: Use keys or indexed columns for joins instead of calculated fields to enhance query performance.
  • Push Logic to HANA: Keep calculations and logic within HANA to leverage pushdown capabilities and minimize SAC-side processing.
  • Blend in HANA, Not SAC: Perform data linking and blending operations in HANA to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Apply Filters Early: Early filtering reduces data load and improves query execution time.
  • Hide Unused Dimensions in SAC: Remove unnecessary metadata from SAC models to streamline performance and reduce clutter.

BW modelling

  • Design Efficient Queries: Limit the number of dimensions and hide unnecessary key figures to reduce query payload and improve responsiveness.
  • Use BW Variables Over SAC Filters: BW variables are processed server-side and offer better performance than applying filters within SAC stories.
  • Define Restricted Key Figures: in BW Avoid creating restricted key figures in SAC remote models. Instead, configure them directly in BW for optimized execution.
  • Minimize Cascading Page Filters: Page-level filters that trigger cascading effects across widgets can slow down performance. Use them sparingly and strategically.
  • Enable Query Merge: Activate query merge to consolidate backend calls, reducing latency and improving load times.
  • Enable HTTP/2 Protocol: Improves data transfer efficiency between SAC and BW, especially for large datasets.
  • Increase Parallel Sessions: Configure BW data sources to support more parallel sessions, enhancing concurrency and user experience.
  • Apply BI Authorizations for Data Security: Use BWâ€™s built-in data-level security to control access and ensure users only retrieve data relevant to their roles.

Story Building Recommendations

Story Structure & Layout

  • Use Optimized or Unified Story Experience: Adopt the latest story building interface for enhanced performance, flexibility, and design capabilities.
  • Leverage Composites as Reusable Widgets: Composites are stored as SAC artifacts and can be reused across stories. They support both canvas and responsive layouts and allow story-level features like filters and bookmarks to apply seamlessly. Benefits include faster story creation, reduced maintenance, standardized design, and support for parallel development.
  • Use Responsive Layouts: Responsive pages automatically adjust to screen size and load faster. Unified stories offer advanced responsive rule configurations for precise control.

Content Design & Performance Optimization

  • Request Only Whatâ€™s Needed: Break down information into manageable layers. Use summary or landing pages with hyperlinks to detailed views.
  • Minimize Page Count and Widget Load: Reduce the number of pages and limit data-heavy widgets per page to improve load times and user experience.
  • Optimize Charts and Tables:
    • Avoid charts with more than 500 data points.
    • Limit the number of charts per page to reduce backend requests.
    • Split large tables into smaller ones with fewer KPIs or measures.
    • Limit the number of cells and descriptive columns for readability.
    • Avoid excessive formatting rules and in-cell charts/calculations.
  • Use Lightweight Visuals:  Replace large image files with lightweight SVGs to reduce rendering time.

Filtering & Data Handling:

  • Implement Filters Strategically: Apply filters at the document level rather than creating generic views. Use page filters instead of individual chart filters. Avoid loading all data and filtering afterward.
  • Limit Hierarchy Depth: in Filters Deep hierarchies can slow down performanceâ€”use only necessary levels.
  • Minimize Data Blending: Sources Keep the number of blended data sources low to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Pause Data Refresh During Design: Use the â€œPause Data Refreshâ€ option to optimize story loading while building.

Security & Access Control

  • Test With User Roles: Validate story performance using roles with end user authorizationsâ€”not just the admin roleâ€”to simulate real-world usage.
  • Apply Data Access Control (DAC): Ensure users only see data relevant to their role. For example, use filters for company code and profit center rather than displaying all dimensions.

Planning-Specific Tips

  • Use Fluid Data Entry Mode: This default mode offers better performance and interactivity. Avoid Single Data Entry mode, which is slower.
  • Enable Planning Only Where Needed: Activate planning features on tables only when required. Disable planning in the builder panel if not used.

Latest Performance Improvements

  • New Table Build Experience:  Optimized Stories â€“ Edit Mode Enhancements.
    • Blended Tables: Initial page loading is faster.
    • Calculations: Automatically retained when tables are copied.
    • Improved Filtering & Sorting: More efficient workflows and reduced query errors.
    • Ghost Table: Instant layout preview before data loads
  • Story Design Optimization:
    • Performance recommendations in Edit Mode available for story designers in the optimized story experience.
    • Available for widget, page, and stories levels.
  • Preload pages
    • It can be enabled in edit mode under Data Refresh->Loading Optimization Settings-> Preload Pages.
    • Preloading will initialize parts of the next and previous page, so switching to these pages will now be faster.

If performance issues persist despite optimization efforts, SAC offers a suite of diagnostic tools to help pinpoint the root cause. These tools provide visibility into query execution, data action performance, and story load behavior. For detailed guidance on using these diagnostics, refer to the official SAP Help documentation or reach out to SAP Support for expert help.

entry.title: Choosing the Right SAP Analytics Tool: Features, Benefits, and Strategy
entry.content:
Introduction : 

Within an organization's data and analytics strategy, SAP provides a portfolio of analytics solutions, including SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), each with a specific function. To assist clients in selecting the best option for their requirements, a comparative analysis of their salient characteristics and advantages is provided below.

SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

Summary: This solution, which is directly integrated into the SAP S/4HANA ERP system, offers real-time analytics on operational data without requiring data replication.

Key Benefits :

  • Operational Reporting in Real Time: Get the most recent information straight from the ERP system.
  • Views of Core Data Services (CDS): For customizable reporting, use virtual data models.
  • Predefined KPIs and Dashboards: Use unconventional content to gain rapid insights.
  • Fiori-Based User Interface: Enhanced user experience through intuitive design.

Benefits:

  • Immediate Decision-Making: Facilitates quick actions based on current data.
  • Simplified Infrastructure: Eliminates the need for separate data warehousing solutions.
  • Seamless Integration: Embedded within the core ERP system, ensuring consistency.

 

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Summary: A cloud-based platform combining business intelligence, planning, and predictive analytics, SAC connects to various data sources, including SAP and non-SAP systems.

Key Features:

  • Advanced Analytics: Utilize AI-driven insights and predictive modelling.
  • Planning Capabilities: Integrate financial planning and budgeting processes.
  • Collaboration Tools: Facilitate real-time discussions and decision-making.
  • Mobile Accessibility: Access analytics on-the-go through optimized dashboards.

Benefits:

  • Comprehensive Insights: Consolidates data from multiple sources for holistic analysis.
  • Enhanced Forecasting: Improves accuracy in planning and budgeting.
  • Scalability: Cloud infrastructure supports growth and flexibility.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)

 Overview: A fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, enabling advanced analytics and AI-driven insights across the organization.

Key Features:

  • Data Integration: Connects disparate data sources into a unified platform.
  • AI and ML Capabilities: Leverages machine learning for predictive analytics.
  • Prebuilt Applications: Offers industry-specific solutions and dashboards.
  • Data Governance: Ensures data quality and compliance across the organization.

Benefits:

  • Accelerated Decision-Making: Provides timely insights for informed decisions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplifies data management and analytics processes.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: Fosters cross-departmental data sharing and insights.

 

Comparative Study

Recommendation:

  • Choose SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics if your primary need is real-time, operational reporting directly within your ERP system, with minimal infrastructure overhead.

  • Opt for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) when you require advanced analytics, predictive modeling, and planning capabilities across various data sources, with a focus on scalability and collaboration.

  • Consider SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) if your organization seeks a unified platform for data integration, governance, and AI-driven insights, encompassing both SAP and third-party data sources.

Thank you for your time.  Stay connected for further updates on Analytics !

-With Warm Regards :  GIRI

entry.title: Full-Page Fit vs. Scrollable Dashboards in SAC which one is better?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'd like to discuss a common dilemma developers face when it comes to designing a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
Should I design the dashboard such that it fits entirely within the browser window (Full-Page Fit)? or should I design the dashboard such that it has a scroll? Would the customer be okay with having to scroll up and down to see the contents of the dashboard? ğŸ™„

So, the design process begins even before we decide to click Create Story.
To Tackle this problem, I will be elaborating both the scenarios for you to make an informed decision while designing your next dashboard.

Difference between both the Dashboard Fit:

Assuming we are seeing the dashboard in a normal sized laptop screen [1366 x 768px] not a 1080p HD one. A Full-Page Fit Dashboard ensures all content is visible without scrolling, while a Scrollable Dashboard allows content to extend vertically or horizontally beyond the initial view, requiring user interaction to access additional information.

This choice significantly impacts user experience and performance. Both has its own advantages and disadvantages. Let's dive deep to understand the pros and cons of each type. 

Full-Page Fit Dashboard: (Everything visible in a single glance)

 Here in the above screenshot, see how all the KPIs presented within a single screen and there is no scroll to the right and bottom of the dashboards. This means that it is well within the boundaries of our 1366 x 768 px canvas.

Advantages

  • All KPIs are visible at a single glance, enabling quick decision-making.
  • No need to scroll, which is ideal for users who prefer a single-screen overview.

Disadvantages

  • Each KPI has less room, potentially less real estate and more congestion.
  • All widgets are triggered simultaneously, sending backend requests that can strain system resources.
  • Heavy widgets like tables may take longer to load, making the dashboard appear sluggish.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs visible in viewport have triggered a backend request and rendered.

It's like going to a restaurant and saying bring me everything you have, even when you know you won't be able to eat everything they bring. Wasteful.ğŸ‘

Total render time ~9.5s 

All the visible KPIs have triggered a backend request and are rendered at Frontend.

Dashboard with Scroll (You gotta scroll to see what you want)

 Scroll Section 1Scroll Section 2

Here in the above screenshot, see how we have a scroll to the right of the dashboard. This means that the KPIs are spaced out more and exceeds the page's default height of 768px, therefore the user would get a scroll when accessing the dashboard.

Advantages

  • More space per KPI allows for better viewability and detailed insights.
  • SACâ€™s viewport loading ensures only visible widgets are triggered, reducing initial load time and backend traffic.
  • Less frequently used or heavier components can be placed lower on the page.

Disadvantages

  • Users may miss the overall picture and need to scroll to compare KPIs.
  • Scrolling back and forth can hinder quick analysis and decision-making.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs that has been viewed initially have triggered a backend request and rendered. The Un scrolled portion doesn't trigger any backend request neither doesn't render until we preview it.

This is like going to the restaurant and placing an order and post eating the main course you get to decide if you want to take on dessert. Only what is required is being consumed here. Resourceful ğŸ‘

Total render time ~8s

 Only KPIs visible during initial preview has been rendered

Finding the Middle Ground: Tab Strips

To balance usability and performance, developers can use Tab Strip.

These are container widgets used within a SAC story to organize content into separate, switchable tabs. They allow users to view different components, such as charts or tables, within a single application by providing a navigation area to select and display the content of each tab.

Tab strip - summary sectionTab strip - Table section

Here in the above screenshot, see how the dashboard is still fitted within the canvas and also having the benefits of loading what is required.

As we have also bifurcated the components into summary and table section. The heavier/Less frequently viewed KPIs are places in the subsequent tab strips, therefore reducing the initial load.

Benefits of Tab Strips

  • Essential KPIs are displayed upfront, while heavier or less frequently accessed components (e.g., raw data tables) are placed in separate tabs.
  • SACâ€™s default viewport loading ensures only visible components are triggered, reducing backend load and improving responsiveness.
  • Tabs offer a cleaner and better UI/UX.

Performance Statistics

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered. The heavier KPIs which hasn't been previewed is still untriggered and unrendered.
Total render time ~7.5s

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered

Key Principle: "What You See Is What Loads"

SAC's viewport optimization means that only the visible components are loaded initially. This explains why Full-Page Fit dashboards can be performance intensive as everything is triggered at once. In contrast, scrollable dashboards and tab-based layouts defer loading of non-visible components, enhancing performance.

However, itâ€™s important to note that once a user navigates to hidden sections or tabs, those components will be triggered, potentially causing a brief delay.

Final Take away

The choice between a Full-Page Fit and a Scrollable Dashboard should be guided by user requirements and usage patterns. Developers must engage with users' early phases in the design process to understand:

  • Which KPIs are most frequently accessed?
  • Is a single-screen overview preferred?
  • Are users comfortable with scrolling or tab navigation?

I hope this article was helpful. Which one do you prefer? Let me know your doubts and opinions in the comments below!

References:

Using the Loading Optimization Setting on a Story Level

entry.title: From Foundation to Future: Master Data Management as the Fuel for Gen AI
entry.content:
In today's fast-paced business landscape, the role of Master Data Management (MDM) has evolved significantly, transitioning from a fundamental process improvement tool to a critical enabler of advanced analytics and AI. Join us for an interactive webinar, "From Foundation to Future: Master Data Management as the Fuel for Gen AI," where we delve into the evolution of MDM and its pivotal role in empowering next-generation AI technologies.

What to Expect

Introduction to The Hackett Group and Their Latest MDM Study

Kickstarting our session, we will introduce The Hackett Group and share insights from their latest 2025 MDM study. This will set the tone for our detailed discussion on the evolution and impact of Master Data Management.

Traditional Applications of MDM

We will then explore the traditional applications of MDM, highlighting its role in business process improvement. Through line-of-business-specific examples, you'll gain a clear understanding of how MDM has been utilized to streamline operations and enhance efficiency.

Contemporary MDM Use Cases

Diving deeper, we will examine more contemporary MDM use cases to illustrate how clean master data drives effective analytics, AI, and ultimately, improved decision-making. These examples will underscore the transformative potential of MDM in today's data-driven world.

SAP Master Data Governance

We will weave in throughout the capabilities of SAP Master Data Governance, demonstrating its role in achieving operational excellence and accurate analytics. Moreover, we will discuss how AI within MDM is driving new value and accelerating business process excellence.

Meet Our Speakers

Bryan DeGraw, Market Intelligence Analyst

Bryan DeGraw, Market Intelligence Analyst at The Hackett Group, is the author of their MDM Matrix Study. His insights and expertise in MDM will provide a comprehensive understanding of its past, present, and future.

Andreas Seifried, SAP MDM Product Management

Andreas Seifried, from SAP MDM Product Management, will share his knowledge on how SAP Master Data Governance can fuel enable businesses to stay ahead in the competitive marketplace.

Why Attend?

1. Insightful Perspectives: Gain valuable insights from industry experts on the evolution of MDM.
2. Practical Examples: Learn from real-world examples that demonstrate the impact of MDM on business processes and decision-making.
3. Future Trends: Understand how MDM is shaping the future of AI and how you can leverage it for your organization.
4. Interactive Session: Engage with our speakers through Q&A sessions and interactive discussions.

Register Now!

Don't miss out on this opportunity to explore how Master Data Management is impacting the business landscape. Register now to stay ahead of the curve and discover how MDM can be the fuel your organization needs to harness the power of Gen AI and secure operational excellence.

We look forward to seeing you at the webinar!

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in September
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in September

Another month with two nice new release deliveries âœ¨

Learn more in my short top features video in September 2025 on YouTube ğŸ“º

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

â€ƒ

My top features in September

 

Input Parameters in Task Chains and Transformation Flows

You can now define input parameters on the task level of task chains and also for transformation flows. A scheduled transformation flow uses the default value of the input parameter. Input parameters defined in transformation flows can be used in operators within the transformation flow, except for the Python operation in Apache Spark runtime.

A transformation flow executed as part of a task chain receives input parameters from the task chain. This will allow for more flexible usage of task chains and even nested task chains.

â¡ï¸  Creating a Transformation Flow

â¡ï¸  Creating Input Parameters in Task Chains

 

Email notification in Replication Flows

You can setup email notifications to stay informed when individual replication objects fail in a running replication flow. From both the Replication Flow editor or the Flows monitor, you can setup an email notification for failures of an individual object in a replication flow.

â¡ï¸  Configure Email Notification for Replication Flow Failure at Object Level

â¡ï¸  Working With Existing Replication Flow Runs

 

Fiscal Time Dimension

When creating a time dimension view, you now have the option for dimension type Standard and Fiscal Time. You use the new Fiscal Time dimension type to model your fiscal time periods and the columns that define their starts and ends. When you add a fiscal time dimension to an analytic model, a Fiscal Variant variable is created for this dimension. The variable can then be handled like any other variable. Its data type is derived from the fiscal variance column from the fiscal time dimension.

â¡ï¸  More information

 

Structure Support for Analytic Models

In order to create restrictions and calculations across all measures of an analytic model, you can create structures. Structures help you to save time and ensure consistency in your calculations, as you donâ€™t need to create a formula/calculation for each measure. In the data preview, the structure members are displayed in their own section. When you use a structure member in the drill-down of a preview, the restriction and calculations defined in the structure member will be applied to each measure. Structures can also be used and enhanced in SAP Analytics Cloud. When the analytic model has measures and at least one structure you need to define how the calculations should be prioritized.

â¡ï¸  More information

entry.title: Sneak Peek in to SAP Analytics Cloud release for Q4 2025
entry.content:
Hard to believe we are at the final quarter of 2025 and what a year it has been. In this blog we give you a sneak peek into our Top 5 features in SAP Analytics Cloud for QRC4 2025. A full list of what is coming can be found on our Roadmap Explorer. Let's dive in!

Horizon Theme

We are excited to announce the introduction of the Horizon themes in SAP Analytics Cloud a modern, cohesive visual language aligned across SAPâ€™s product suite. You will have access to Morning and Evening Horizon, the light and dark themes as well as to the high contrast white and black themes.

 

To learn more about this and other usability enhancement check out this great blog by @AnnaBurkhardt

 

My Metrics for KPIs Monitoring (formerly known as Watchlist)

A much anticipated new feature is the introduction of My Metrics (fka Watchlist). My Metrics to create lists of metrics that you want to monitor, analyze, and share with other stakeholders. Add to a metrics list from a chart's context menu within a story. You can gain insights of the data changes and organize important metrics associated with your business in an intuitive way. With this new feature users can enjoy:

  • New design that enables you to add and monitor your KPIs within SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Ability to create, manage, and share your Metric Lists
  • Ability for viewers to add KPIs directly from stories
  • Customized comparisons and previews

To learn more check out this great blog by @marouferchichi 

Seamless Planning

We have two exciting additions to Seamless Planning this quarter, SAP Datasphere fact view as a live version in a planning model and the ability to Scheduling a story based on a live SAP Datasphere solution connection.

Let's start with the ability to consume an existing SAP Datasphere fact view live using a separate version dimension element within a planning model:

  • Version element is available for consumption within stories (read-only in table)
  • Version element can be used as a source for planning operations, including copy and paste from an external version to a local version, or in batch operations, such as data actions, as a source or reference for copy and calculation operations

We have also added the ability to schedule and deliver a story based on a live connection of SAP Datasphere to users over e-mail through SAP Analytics Cloud.

 These are just 2 new features in the Seamless Planning story and there are many other in this great blog by @Max_Gander 

Scheduling & Process Management: Factory Calendar

Staying with planning we also introduce the ability to schedule calendar tasks and publications based on working days. This includes the ability to:

  • Define a custom property representing workdays as an attribute in a model time dimension
  • View working days within the calendar and Gantt view
  • Set task recurrence based on working days

 

 

SAP Analytics Cloud Performance Content: Model and audit table sizes

For administrators and system owners of SAP Analytics Cloud, maintaining a high-performing and stable environment is a top priority. As organizations expand their use of SAC, managing the underlying data volumes becomes increasingly important.

So in this release we are delivering a new Story in SAC Content designed to give you the transparency and control you need to manage your SAC tenant's data footprint effectively. This Story serves as a central overview for monitoring, analyzing, and then to be able to take an informed action on data volumes before they become a critical issue.

 

For further details check out this great blog by @thomas_fery 

There are plenty more exciting deliverables coming your way this quarter and we will be taking a deeper dive into these items in our Whatâ€™s New video and blog series so stay tuned. For a full list of all features coming in QRC3 2025 for SAP Analytics Cloud check out the Roadmap Explorer  and the What's New Viewer

Want to experience new and existing features for yourself? Take the leap and start your journey towards making data-driven decisions with confidence by signing up for a free trial, today.

entry.title: Maximize the value of HR data â€“ Introducing People Intelligence
entry.content:
We are excited to introduce people Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud â€“ People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is the new People Analytics solution from SAP based on the fully managed Business Data Cloud that unifies and governs data from SAP SuccessFactors, other SAP and non-SAP sources while preserving its original business context to enable analytics. Designed for HR leaders, HR Business Partners, Managers and many other personas, the solution helps answer some of the most important and critical business questions through prebuilt insight applications.

 The problem

Data is the new currency and HR data has even more potential but, the reality is that most of this data remains fragmented, scattered across silos, locked in incompatible formats, or inaccessible in real time. This fragmentation hinders agility, quick decision-making, and slows innovation. As HR landscapes evolve rapidly and competition intensifies, companies need more than just access to dataâ€”they need clarity, coherence, and the ability to act on insights with confidence and speed. Additional complexities arise when we want to make this data available for powering AI scenarios and enriching the data leveraging machine learning and Data Science capabilities.

Our solution

To address these data silos and solve these business challenges faced by HR Leaders, weâ€™re introducing People Intelligence â€“ A solution that transforms people, skills, Learning, Recruiting, and talent data into actionable, AI-driven insights. It is a collection of insight Applications around SuccessFactors Core HR, Skills, Recruiting, Learning and talent modules. Many of these insight apps have been built to showcase broad spectrum of insights from these modules and many more to be added covering the other modules as per the published roadmap.

Some of the key Insights that HR leaders can derive through people Intelligence are -

  • Talent Flow Analytics,
  • Knowing if they are building Skills led future-ready organization?
  • Our investments in learning are improving skills proficiencies and how does it impact employee performance?
  • Are we paying for performance and how is our ethnicity and gender pay gap?

 People Intelligence is built on SAP Business Data Cloud(BDC)

As stated earlier, BDC is a fully managed Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution designed to unify, govern, and make sense of data across the entire business landscape. It brings together SAP and non-SAP data into one trusted, business-ready foundationâ€”enabling decision-makers access real-time insights with full context. By connecting siloed information through a powerful semantic layer and open data ecosystem, SAP BDC transforms raw data into a strategic asset. BDC brings this powerful functionality of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, plus managed SAP Databricks, intelligent applications, and data products.

Data Products are curated data sets, the meta data that describes the data set and an API to exchange the data.
Data Products are then used in realising SAP Datasphere Analytic models that power SAP Analytic Cloud stories or Planning scenarios.
Each insight App that is part of People Intelligence is based on SAP curated semantic models, which provide customers with tailored insights and actionable recommendations out-of-the-box.

List of Insight Apps delivered as part of People Intelligence GA:

  • Workforce composition Insights : Visualize workforce composition by role, location, demographics, and org structure, and track how talent flows through the organization by analysing movements, new-hires and terminations data.
  • Skills Insights: See current employee skills, identify role-level gaps (as-is vs. required proficiency), and track which skills are rising or declining across the organization.
  • Workforce Compensation(EC based) Insights: Gain clear compensation visibility by viewing average salaries by role, grade, and location, analysing compa-ratio organization-wide, and comparing pay for terminated employees versus new hires.
  • Recruiting Insights: Reduce time-to-hire and recruitment costs by uncovering the most effective talent sources and ensuring project success by filling open positions faster.
  • Learning Insights: Drive agility across your teams through targeted trainings that closes essential Skills and Proficiency gaps.
  • Performance Insights: Drive productivity and fairness by connecting performance trends to compensation, promotion rate and turnover outcomes.
  • Goals Insights: Ensure goal-setting aligns with organizational strategy and includes progress tracking to completion.
  • Succession Insights: Build a stronger leadership pipeline by evaluating successor readiness, uncovering risk areas, by refining talent pool readiness and succession strategies.
  • Career Development Planning(CDP) Insights: Enhance retention and engagement through tailored, actionable insights into employee development goals.

Through all of these Insight Apps we have enabled access to Data Analyzer which helps the user with a predefined ready-to-run service for multidimensional, pivot styled ad-hoc analysis using our Datasphere models directly.

Another notable feature that is made available in all of the Insight Apps is a A/B comparison utility which helps compare key measure values like headcount etc., by bringing them side by side and by selecting dimensions like location, organization unit, job classification etc., This helps the persona discover the headcount changes between the two locations or by the other selected dimensions in an intuitive manner.

People Intelligence â€“ Product Capabilities:

  • Access semantically rich Data Products across all SuccessFactors Modules provided by a scalable SAP managed Data Lake.
  • Access to cross SAP Data Products comprising harmonized data across SAP LOBs discoverable via the central data product catalog.
  • Integrate Data from non-SAP systems into Business Data Cloud.
  • Utilize ready to run insights with out-of-the-box analytical models and dashboards for SuccessFactors modules and cross LOB use-cases.
  • Leverage the power of SAP Business Data Cloud stack to extend the pre-delivered content or create your own analytical application.
  • Enable your data engineers and data scientists to perform pro-code data engineering, data science, custom AI/ML and advanced analytics use-cases.
  • Close the action to insight gap by bringing analytics into the flow of your users in SuccessFactors via Joule.

In summary, People Intelligence helps Drive better HR and business performance with proactively delivered, AI-driven insights and help them stay ahead by continually adapting and optimizing with agility.

Whatâ€™s Next

Watch this space for separate blog posts to cover the various insight Apps that we are delivering as part of People Intelligence, the business questions they answer etc.,

Please check the official BDC Roadmap for a comprehensive overview of forthcoming features not just as part of People Intelligence but also BDC.

Resources to know more about People Intelligence:

  • Know more about SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Watch our Success Connect solution deep dive (registration required).
  • Register for our upcoming webinars on People Intelligence: "Drive Better Workforce Decisions with a New Approach to People Analytics"

entry.title: Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)

JDBC â€“ JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY

Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API :
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access.

Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. Iâ€™ll cover this with a clear explanation in an upcoming post.

Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).

For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section.

Prerequisites:

  1. SAP DataSphere â€“ Subscribed account (âš  Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported)
  2. SAP Integration Suite â€“ Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported)

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide :

Step

Action / Notes

1. Create a Space

DataSphere â†’ Space Management â†’ New Space â†’ Name it â†’ Create.

2. Create Table / Analytical Model

Data Builder â†’ In your Space â†’ New â†’ Table or Analytical Model â†’ define fields & data types â†’ Save & Publish.
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. *

3. Prepare / Load Data

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration.

4. Note Schema & Object Names

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use.
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name *

5. Decide Where to Create DB User

If HANA Cloud â†’ use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB â†’ use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin.
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session*

6. Create JDBC DB User

DB admin tool â†’ Security/Users â†’ New User â†’ set username & strong password â†’ Save.
*Check Active status of User*

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign.

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
Format for CPI JDBC Material:
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true


SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide :

Create a Package & Artifact

  • In CPI â†’ Design â†’ Create a new package â†’ Add an integration flow artifact.
  • âœ… Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts.

Go to Monitoring â†’ JDBC Material

  • In CPI â†’ Monitor â†’ Integrations and APIs â†’ Manage Security â†’ JDBC Material

     

  • â†’ Add JDBC Data Source. â†’ Select HANA cloud

     



  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true).

     

  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere).

     

  • Save and deploy the JDBC material.

Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

  • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter â†’ select the JDBC data source created.
  • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, Iâ€™m using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

 


Step 1: Timer Start
 In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule â†’ None â†’ On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

 


Step 2: Content Modifier
Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
 SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

 



Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
 â†’ Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
â†’ JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

 


Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

References :
same blog by me for clear picture quality: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JD... - SAP Community
CPI JDBC â€“ XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
 link:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in October
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in October

Another month with a great new release delivery âœ¨

Learn more in my short top features video in October2025 on YouTube ğŸ“º also including an outlook at SAP TechEd session this year.

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

My top features in October

 

Impact of Changes in the Source Objects of an Analytic Model

Changing, saving, and re-deploying a data builder object again will trigger a status change of any analytic model that uses that object. The analytic model status will change to either â€œChanges to Deployâ€ or â€œDesign Time Errorâ€, depending on which change has been made (compatible or incompatible changes). This gives you better transparency in change control handling of your models.

 

Converting a Data Flow Into a Replication Flow and/or Transformation Flow

When your data flow is eligible to be converted into a transformation flow or a replication flow coupled with a transformation flow, a banner will be displayed in the data flow editor. Using a replication flow and/or a transformation flow will allow you to benefit from improved connectivity, access to delta load processing, and enhanced resiliency and scalability.
â¡ï¸   More information

 

Technical User to Manage Tasks via CLI

You can now use OAuth clients with the technical user purpose to manage tasks via the command line interface based on the roles and spaces you assign to the client.
â¡ï¸   More information.

 

 

 

SAP TechEd 2025

There are many sessions about SAP Business Data Cloud and also SAP Datasphere at SAP TechEd 2025. Some are part of the virtual TechEd and others like for instance the onsite hands-on sessions are exclusive for people attending in Berlin.

@VenkatPSis looking at the same topic from a use case perspective and explains the problems which can be solved using this application:

Keep on brining these valuable blogs @FernandaFroelich. On the one hand she extend her blog series on SAP Databricks by looking more detailed on user and roles with Databricks:

On the other hand, she helps you to better understand the consumption monitoring in SAP BDC:

entry.title: SAP HANA Cloud Becomes Agentic: Introducing Discovery Agent & Data Agent
entry.content:
The Challenge

Enterprises today work with massive volumes of data spread across tables, views, JSON collections, graphs, and text. Yet most users donâ€™t know where that data lives or how to access it efficiently. Building a bridge between business questions and the underlying technical data model often requires deep schema knowledge and SQL expertise.

At the same time, users expect to â€œtalk to their dataâ€, to search, ask, and get answers without navigating complex structures. But creating such experiences has often been challenging. Data is often siloed, metadata is hard to navigate, and the context needed to connect insights is missing.

The Innovation: Discovery Agent and Data Agent in SAP HANA Cloud (planned QRC1 2026)

At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP HANA Cloud takes a major step forward by becoming agentic and introducing a suite of agents designed to simplify how people discover and interact with data.

In this blog, the focus will be on the Discovery Agent and the Data Agent.
Together, they make it easier for agent users to find the right data objects, understand relationships, and generate the right queries, all without needing deep technical or SQL knowledge.

Discovery Agent: Exploring data context

The Discovery Agent helps users find and understand the data available in SAP HANA Cloud. It explores the HANA catalog using a Knowledge Graph that exposes how objects relate to one another, making it easy to locate relevant datasets without manually browsing schemas. When users describe what they need, like for example, project details or customer transactions, the Discovery Agent can identify the right data sources based on context, relationships, and annotations. Under the hood, the agent generates SPARQL queries on the RDF graph of HANA objects, revealing how data structures connect.

Data Agent: Turning intent into executable queries

Once the relevant data objects are found, the Data Agent takes over.
It translates natural language intent into executable queries, such as SQL. Users can simply describe what they want to retrieve, for instance, â€œshow my current projects with partner involvementâ€ and the Data Agent generates and executes the corresponding query.

By combining discovery and query generation, these agents make data exploration seamless: the Discovery Agent provides context, while the Data Agent delivers answers.

Powered by the SAP HANA Cloud Custom Database Objects Knowledge Graph (planned QRC1 2026)

At the core of these agents lies the Custom Database Objects Knowledge Graph: an RDF graph automatically built from system catalog that captures tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It provides the semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning, forming the foundation for richer, AI ready data discovery in SAP HANA Cloud. What used to take days of manual modeling can now be done automatically in minutes.

Create a custom database objects knowledge graph on SAP HANA Cloud Central

This Knowledge Graph allows agents to reason about data, to understand how entities connect, what relationships exist, and which attributes are relevant. It is the foundation that enables both discovery and querying to work contextually and at scale.

 

How It Works

Imagine a business user who doesnâ€™t know the database schema or table names, they simply have a question in mind and want to â€œtalk to the database.â€

For example, they might ask: â€œList all customers with their sales conversion probability and related details?â€

Hereâ€™s what happens behind the scenes:

  1. The Discovery Agent searches the Database Objects Knowledge Graph to identify which tables and views contain the relevant data.
  2. The Data Agent then uses that information to generate a query that retrieves the results without any manual lookup or SQL writing required.

In a few seconds, the user receives a clear answer. The process feels conversational, even though the agents are performing complex discovery and query generation under the hood.

Ask a Natural Language Query on your database objects, via Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central

Explore insights built on the actual database objects and relationships in your SAP HANA Cloud instance.

 

Enables Data Discovery

With the Discovery and Data Agents, SAP HANA Cloud transforms metadata into a living semantic layer that spans its multi-model engines. The â€œagent usersâ€ can now query their data environment conversationally, explore hidden relationships, and even surface annotations and sample values to guide analytics. Together, these agents transform SAP HANA Cloud from a static data platform into a dynamic environment where users can reason, explore, and interact with data naturally.

Looking Ahead: Context and Memory for Agents (Product Vision)

The journey toward an agentic SAP HANA Cloud is just beginning. As these capabilities evolve, context and long-term memory will play a key role in shaping the next generation of agents. Future agents will not only discover and query data but also retain context from previous interactions, remembering what was asked, which datasets were used, and what outcomes were returned. Over time, this could enable more natural and connected conversations with data, where insights evolve instead of starting from scratch each time.
This concept of Agentic Memory will help create more continuous and connected user experiences, all while leveraging HANA Cloudâ€™s trusted data management and governance foundation.

Conclusion:

Together, these agents make SAP HANA Cloud the foundation for a new generation of secure, context-aware, and agent-driven data experiences.

For agent users, this means:

  • A unified way to access data and metadata.
  • Natural-language querying through familiar protocols (MCP).
  • The potential for context persistence across multi-turn conversations.
  • A path toward AI-grounded data exploration and graph-enhanced analytics.

With that, itâ€™s certain: SAP HANA Cloud is THE database for SAPâ€™s AI-native software architecture. For additional updates and announcements from SAP TechEd 2025, check @thomashammer 's blogpost here
